metadata.name: Credential Manager Access By Uncommon Applications
metadata.comment: Detects suspicious processes based on name and location that access the windows credential manager and vault. Which can be a sign of credential stealing. Example case would be usage of mimikatz "dpapi::cred" function

batch.sql: SELECT * FROM file_activity WHERE time BETWEEN CURRENT_TIMESTAMP() - INTERVAL 24 HOUR AND CURRENT_TIMESTAMP() AND ((contains(lower(file.name), lower('\\\\appdata\\\\local\\\\microsoft\\\\credentials\\\\')) OR contains(lower(file.name), lower('\\\\appdata\\\\roaming\\\\microsoft\\\\credentials\\\\')) OR contains(lower(file.name), lower('\\\\appdata\\\\local\\\\microsoft\\\\vault\\\\')) OR contains(lower(file.name), lower('\\\\programdata\\\\microsoft\\\\vault\\\\'))) AND NOT (startswith(lower(actor.process.name), lower('c:\\\\program files\\\\')) OR startswith(lower(actor.process.name), lower('c:\\\\program files (x86)\\\\')) OR startswith(lower(actor.process.name), lower('c:\\\\windows\\\\system32\\\\')) OR startswith(lower(actor.process.name), lower('c:\\\\windows\\\\syswow64\\\\'))))

output.summary: Detects suspicious processes based on name and location that access the windows credential manager and vault. Which can be a sign of credential stealing. Example case would be usage of mimikatz "dpapi::cred" function

metadata.objective: False positive: Legitimate software installed by the users for example in the "AppData" directory may access these files (for any reason). References: https://hunter2.gitbook.io/darthsidious/privilege-escalation/mimikatz, https://www.absolomb.com/2018-01-26-Windows-Privilege-Escalation-Guide/
